Key.Original: Emitter 3Ditor
Key.English: Emitter 3Ditor

Key.Original: Emitter 3Ditor Internal funcs
Key.English: Emitter 3Ditor Internal funcs

Key.Original: Emitter 3Ditor Misc
Key.English: Emitter 3Ditor Misc

Key.Original: Emitter 3Ditor 'In-Game' functions
Key.English: Emitter 3Ditor 'In-Game' functions

Key.Original: Welcome to using <%2>Emitter 3Ditor<%3>. This a tour of the tool GUI, it's a bit long one so you should probably bring some Trail Mix..
Key.English: Welcome to using <%2>Emitter 3Ditor<%3>. This a tour of the tool GUI, it's a bit long one so you should probably bring some Trail Mix..

Key.Original:
The <%2>Emitter Editor<%3> is comprised of two sections, <%2>Particle Editor<%3> and <%2>Light Editor<%3>.
Particle Editor is indicated by the button with the flame icon. Whenever a section is selected it's button is glowing green.
Keyboard shortcut: <%2><%10>ALT + F1<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The <%2>Emitter Editor<%3> is comprised of two sections, <%2>Particle Editor<%3> and <%2>Light Editor<%3>.
Particle Editor is indicated by the button with the flame icon. Whenever a section is selected it's button is glowing green.
Keyboard shortcut: <%2><%10>ALT + F1<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Light Editor<%3> is indicated by the button with the lightbulp icon.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ALT + F2<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Light Editor<%3> is indicated by the button with the lightbulp icon.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ALT + F2<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
We'll look at Particle Editor first.
Press <%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> on your keyboard to place a particle emitter in the Eden edit area on the mouse cursor position.
Key.English:
We'll look at Particle Editor first.
Press <%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> on your keyboard to place a particle emitter in the Eden edit area on the mouse cursor position.

Key.Original:
The emitter will appear in the tool's <%2>Emitter list<%3>, as well as in the Eden entity list as all regular Eden entities do.
When the first emitter is added the rest of the tool UI becomes active.
Key.English:
The emitter will appear in the tool's <%2>Emitter list<%3>, as well as in the Eden entity list as all regular Eden entities do.
When the first emitter is added the rest of the tool UI becomes active.

Key.Original:
The placed emitter will get a 'default' particle class applied to it which in case of vanilla particles is the first class in the <%2>Emitter Class List<%3>; 'AirFireSparks'.
NOTE that if mods are used this list may contain more than the vanilla classes, and the first class may be something else that 'AirFireSparks'.
Key.English:
The placed emitter will get a 'default' particle class applied to it which in case of vanilla particles is the first class in the <%2>Emitter Class List<%3>; 'AirFireSparks'.
NOTE that if mods are used this list may contain more than the vanilla classes, and the first class may be something else that 'AirFireSparks'.

Key.Original: From the class list you can select a class to apply to your emitter if you wish to do so.
Key.English: From the class list you can select a class to apply to your emitter if you wish to do so.

Key.Original:
With the <%2>delete button<%3> you can delete the currently selected emitter. NOTE that this requires a double-click to avoid accidental deletion.
You can of course delete the emitter just by hovering over it and pressing <%2>DELETE<%3> on your keyboard just like any Eden entity.
Key.English:
With the <%2>delete button<%3> you can delete the currently selected emitter. NOTE that this requires a double-click to avoid accidental deletion.
You can of course delete the emitter just by hovering over it and pressing <%2>DELETE<%3> on your keyboard just like any Eden entity.

Key.Original:
With the <%2>Cam On<%3> button you can move the camera closer to the currently selected emitter (like pressing <%2>HOME<%3> to move the camera to the player entity).
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>CTRL + HOME<%3><%3>
Key.English:
With the <%2>Cam On<%3> button you can move the camera closer to the currently selected emitter (like pressing <%2>HOME<%3> to move the camera to the player entity).
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>CTRL + HOME<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
With the <%2>R<%3> button you can rename the currently selected emitter. <%2><%10>The emitter attributes CAN NOT be opened at all, so the only way to rename them is via the tool.<%3><%3>
Keyboard shortcut: <%11><%2>ALT + R<%3><%3>
Key.English:
With the <%2>R<%3> button you can rename the currently selected emitter. <%2><%10>The emitter attributes CAN NOT be opened at all, so the only way to rename them is via the tool.<%3><%3>
Keyboard shortcut: <%11><%2>ALT + R<%3><%3>

Key.Original: This button is called <%2>Attachmode Selector<%3>. This will be detailed in the tutorial <%10><%2>'Attaching Emitters'<%3><%3>
Key.English: This button is called <%2>Attachmode Selector<%3>. This will be detailed in the tutorial <%10><%2>'Attaching Emitters'<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
With the <%2>Clone<%3> button you can clone an emitter or an entity with attribute emitters.
<%2>NOTE that normal Eden copy/paste does not work with the emiters<%3>.

This will be detailed in the tutorial <%10><%2>'Cloning Emitters'<%3><%3>
Key.English:
With the <%2>Clone<%3> button you can clone an emitter or an entity with attribute emitters.
<%2>NOTE that normal Eden copy/paste does not work with the emiters<%3>.

This will be detailed in the tutorial <%10><%2>'Cloning Emitters'<%3><%3>

Key.Original: This button is called <%2>Clear class<%3>. It will revert the selected emitter to it's default particle class (with vanilla classes to 'AirFireSparks')
Key.English: This button is called <%2>Clear class<%3>. It will revert the selected emitter to it's default particle class (with vanilla classes to 'AirFireSparks')

Key.Original:
With this button you can disable/enable the emitter(s) emitting in the editor (they will still emit in preview). When enabled the button reads <%2>DISABLE<%3>, when disabled it reads <%2>ENABLE<%3>.
It disables/enables all emitters in the scenario, or if you hold down <%10><%2>ALT<%3><%3> while pressing this button it will only disable/enable the selected emitter(s). If no emitters are selected will disable all.
Disabled emitter names turn red.
Keyboard shortcuts:
<%10><%2>ALT + D<%3><%3> - disable selected
<%10><%2>CTRL + D<%3><%3> - disable all
Key.English:
With this button you can disable/enable the emitter(s) emitting in the editor (they will still emit in preview). When enabled the button reads <%2>DISABLE<%3>, when disabled it reads <%2>ENABLE<%3>.
It disables/enables all emitters in the scenario, or if you hold down <%10><%2>ALT<%3><%3> while pressing this button it will only disable/enable the selected emitter(s). If no emitters are selected will disable all.
Disabled emitter names turn red.
Keyboard shortcuts:
<%10><%2>ALT + D<%3><%3> - disable selected
<%10><%2>CTRL + D<%3><%3> - disable all

Key.Original:
This button hides the tool from view. To get it back press <%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3> on you keyboard.
<%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3> is also the keyboard shortcut for this hide/unhide tool.
Key.English:
This button hides the tool from view. To get it back press <%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3> on you keyboard.
<%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3> is also the keyboard shortcut for this hide/unhide tool.

Key.Original: When you hide the tool with the hide button or <%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3> a 'reveal' button is shown on the status bar. If you press it (or <%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3>) the tool UI will re-appear.
Key.English: When you hide the tool with the hide button or <%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3> a 'reveal' button is shown on the status bar. If you press it (or <%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3>) the tool UI will re-appear.

Key.Original:
This is the tool <%2>main menu<%3>. For the Particle Editor section it includes 8 'leafs'.
The leafs will be covered in more detail in their individual tutorial sections.
Key.English:
This is the tool <%2>main menu<%3>. For the Particle Editor section it includes 8 'leafs'.
The leafs will be covered in more detail in their individual tutorial sections.

Key.Original:
<%2>!!VERY IMPORTANT NOTE!!<%3>

Each edit field on this tool's UI is 'armed' with data verification so that the data you input in it is proper for the emitter to consume.
Data types are:
%1Number
%1String
%1Array.
Key.English:
<%2>!!VERY IMPORTANT NOTE!!<%3>

Each edit field on this tool's UI is 'armed' with data verification so that the data you input in it is proper for the emitter to consume.
Data types are:
%1Number
%1String
%1Array.

Key.Original:
<%2>!!VERY IMPORTANT NOTE!!<%3>

When you input something into the field the field input and edges will turn yellow which indicates the data is being validated. During this you shouldn't try to continue typing into the field.
Key.English:
<%2>!!VERY IMPORTANT NOTE!!<%3>

When you input something into the field the field input and edges will turn yellow which indicates the data is being validated. During this you shouldn't try to continue typing into the field.

Key.Original:
<%2>!!VERY IMPORTANT NOTE!!<%3>

If the data validates succesfully the edit field turns back to normal.
If the data is faulty the edit field turns red and you will get a error notification as well.
After a couple of seconds the edit field is filled with either it's default data or the last valid input.
Key.English:
<%2>!!VERY IMPORTANT NOTE!!<%3>

If the data validates succesfully the edit field turns back to normal.
If the data is faulty the edit field turns red and you will get a error notification as well.
After a couple of seconds the edit field is filled with either it's default data or the last valid input.

Key.Original:
The first leaf is <%2>Basic Params<%3>. This includes most of the parameters you would set with the scripting command setParticleParams (apart from the 'Attached to' and 'selection' which are tool specific).
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 1<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The first leaf is <%2>Basic Params<%3>. This includes most of the parameters you would set with the scripting command setParticleParams (apart from the 'Attached to' and 'selection' which are tool specific).
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 1<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The second leaf is <%2>Render Params<%3>. This includes rest of the parameters you would set with the scripting command setParticleParams.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 2<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The second leaf is <%2>Render Params<%3>. This includes rest of the parameters you would set with the scripting command setParticleParams.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 2<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The third leaf is <%2>Random<%3>. This includes the parameters you would set with setParticleRandom.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 3<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The third leaf is <%2>Random<%3>. This includes the parameters you would set with setParticleRandom.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 3<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The fourth leaf is <%2>Circle<%3>. This includes the parameters you would set with setParticleCircle.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 4<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The fourth leaf is <%2>Circle<%3>. This includes the parameters you would set with setParticleCircle.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 4<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The fifth leaf is <%2>Damage<%3>. This includes the parameters you would set with setParticleFire.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 5<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The fifth leaf is <%2>Damage<%3>. This includes the parameters you would set with setParticleFire.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 5<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The sixth leaf is <%2>Special<%3>. This includes some tool specific params that have nothing to do with the particle related scripting commands.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 6<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The sixth leaf is <%2>Special<%3>. This includes some tool specific params that have nothing to do with the particle related scripting commands.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 6<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The seventh leaf is <%2>Export/import<%3>. This is for exporting and importing particle params, saving and loading particle presets.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 7<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The seventh leaf is <%2>Export/import<%3>. This is for exporting and importing particle params, saving and loading particle presets.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 7<%3><%3>

Key.Original: <%2>Save Preset<%3> is for saving your fave particle effects as presets.
Key.English: <%2>Save Preset<%3> is for saving your fave particle effects as presets.

Key.Original: <%2>Load Preset<%3> is for loading the saved particle presets.
Key.English: <%2>Load Preset<%3> is for loading the saved particle presets.

Key.Original: <%2>Paste Params<%3> is for 'injecting' particle params into the emitters pasted from some script for example.
Key.English: <%2>Paste Params<%3> is for 'injecting' particle params into the emitters pasted from some script for example.

Key.Original: <%2>Export<%3> is for exporting particle parameters into the clipboard and .rpt file. You don't really need to do that but it's there for convinience.
Key.English: <%2>Export<%3> is for exporting particle parameters into the clipboard and .rpt file. You don't really need to do that but it's there for convinience.

Key.Original:
The eight leaf is <%2>Prefs<%3>. In here you can find some preferences you can set for the tool.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 8<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The eight leaf is <%2>Prefs<%3>. In here you can find some preferences you can set for the tool.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 8<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
That's it for the Particle Editor UI.
On to the Light Editor UI...

NOTE that for the purposes of the tutorial the time is adjusted so that it becomes dark.
Key.English:
That's it for the Particle Editor UI.
On to the Light Editor UI...

NOTE that for the purposes of the tutorial the time is adjusted so that it becomes dark.

Key.Original:
<%2>Light Editor<%3> is indicated by the button with the lightbulp icon.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ALT + F2<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Light Editor<%3> is indicated by the button with the lightbulp icon.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ALT + F2<%3><%3>

Key.Original: Same as with particles, press <%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> on your keyboard to insert a light emitter in the Eden edit area on the mouse cursor position.
Key.English: Same as with particles, press <%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> on your keyboard to insert a light emitter in the Eden edit area on the mouse cursor position.

Key.Original:
The emitter will appear in the tool's <%2>Emitter list<%3>, as well as in the Eden entity list as all regular Eden entities do.
When the first emitter is added the rest of the tool UI becomes active.
Key.English:
The emitter will appear in the tool's <%2>Emitter list<%3>, as well as in the Eden entity list as all regular Eden entities do.
When the first emitter is added the rest of the tool UI becomes active.

Key.Original: The placed emitter will get a 'empty' light class applied to it, meaning it will not emit any light.
Key.English: The placed emitter will get a 'empty' light class applied to it, meaning it will not emit any light.

Key.Original:
From the class list you can select a class to apply to your emitter if you wish to do so.
NOTE that light emitters don't like VR in Eden so they tend to keel over so the light 'points' to the side. Will not appear like that when previewing.
Key.English:
From the class list you can select a class to apply to your emitter if you wish to do so.
NOTE that light emitters don't like VR in Eden so they tend to keel over so the light 'points' to the side. Will not appear like that when previewing.

Key.Original: The top menu of the tool: emitter list, delete and other buttons and so on stay the same, what changes is from the main menu onwards.
Key.English: The top menu of the tool: emitter list, delete and other buttons and so on stay the same, what changes is from the main menu onwards.

Key.Original:
This is the <%2>Light Editor main menu<%3>. It includes 5 'leafs'.
The leafs will be covered in more detail in their individual tutorial sections.
Key.English:
This is the <%2>Light Editor main menu<%3>. It includes 5 'leafs'.
The leafs will be covered in more detail in their individual tutorial sections.

Key.Original:
The first leaf is <%2>Light Params<%3>. This includes all the parameters that you would set with all the setLightBlahblah commands, plus some of the tool specific things that were in their separate leaf in the Particle Editor.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 1<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The first leaf is <%2>Light Params<%3>. This includes all the parameters that you would set with all the setLightBlahblah commands, plus some of the tool specific things that were in their separate leaf in the Particle Editor.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 1<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The second leaf is <%2>Save Preset<%3>. This is for saving your fave lights as presets. In Particle Editor this is hidden deeper under Export/Import.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 2<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The second leaf is <%2>Save Preset<%3>. This is for saving your fave lights as presets. In Particle Editor this is hidden deeper under Export/Import.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 2<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The third leaf is <%2>Load Preset<%3>. For loading the light presets saved in the previous leaf. In the Particle editor this is hidden deeper under Export/Import.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 3<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The third leaf is <%2>Load Preset<%3>. For loading the light presets saved in the previous leaf. In the Particle editor this is hidden deeper under Export/Import.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 3<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The fourth leaf is <%2>Export/Import<%3>. This is for exporting and importing light parameters.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 4<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The fourth leaf is <%2>Export/Import<%3>. This is for exporting and importing light parameters.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 4<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
The fifth leaf is <%2>Prefs<%3>. This is exactly the same as the Prefs in the Particle Editor, currently there is no section specific preferences.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 5<%3><%3>
Key.English:
The fifth leaf is <%2>Prefs<%3>. This is exactly the same as the Prefs in the Particle Editor, currently there is no section specific preferences.
Keyboard shortcut : <%10><%2>CTRL + 5<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
Done.

Read the full manual that came with the download for further and more detailed information.
Key.English:
Done.

Read the full manual that came with the download for further and more detailed information.

Key.Original: Tool UI
Key.English: Tool UI

Key.Original: Preferences Leaf
Key.English: Preferences Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Preferences<%3>
The tool specific preferences and 'default emitter set' setup.
Key.English:
<%2>Preferences<%3>
The tool specific preferences and 'default emitter set' setup.

Key.Original:
<%2>Always start with Eden<%3>
Does exactly that, when this is checked the tool will always start up with Eden when you open it.
Key.English:
<%2>Always start with Eden<%3>
Does exactly that, when this is checked the tool will always start up with Eden when you open it.

Key.Original:
<%2>Select tool to start up with Eden.<%3>
When Tool is set to start up with Eden with this you can select which editor section the tool starts with.
Key.English:
<%2>Select tool to start up with Eden.<%3>
When Tool is set to start up with Eden with this you can select which editor section the tool starts with.

Key.Original:
<%2>Always start hidden<%3>
When Tool is set to start up with Eden with this you can select whether the tool starts up hidden (same as hiding it with the hide button or CTRL + BACKSPACE).
Key.English:
<%2>Always start hidden<%3>
When Tool is set to start up with Eden with this you can select whether the tool starts up hidden (same as hiding it with the hide button or CTRL + BACKSPACE).

Key.Original:
<%2>Show emitter names in 3D/map<%3>
Toggle showing the emitter names in the 3D edit area and on the map.
Key.English:
<%2>Show emitter names in 3D/map<%3>
Toggle showing the emitter names in the 3D edit area and on the map.

Key.Original:
<%2>Auto-change tool section<%3>
When this is toggled the tool section is automatically switched according to the emitter type when you select an emitter. Selecting particle emitter switches to particle editor, selecting light emitter switches to light editor..
Key.English:
<%2>Auto-change tool section<%3>
When this is toggled the tool section is automatically switched according to the emitter type when you select an emitter. Selecting particle emitter switches to particle editor, selecting light emitter switches to light editor..

Key.Original:
<%2>Version<%3>
Shows the current installed version of the tool. If reporting bugs it's useful to include this to the report.
Key.English:
<%2>Version<%3>
Shows the current installed version of the tool. If reporting bugs it's useful to include this to the report.

Key.Original:
<%2>Toggle default emitter set<%3>
Toggle placing a <%2>default emitter set<%3> with <%10><%2>SHIFT + INSERT<%3><%3>.
Default emitter set is a set of up to 4 emitters you can define and place when this is toggled on.
Key.English:
<%2>Toggle default emitter set<%3>
Toggle placing a <%2>default emitter set<%3> with <%10><%2>SHIFT + INSERT<%3><%3>.
Default emitter set is a set of up to 4 emitters you can define and place when this is toggled on.

Key.Original:
<%2>Always insert defaults<%3>
When this is toggled you can not place single emitters, the default emitter set will always be inserted whether you press <%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> or <%10><%2>SHIFT + INSERT<%3><%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Always insert defaults<%3>
When this is toggled you can not place single emitters, the default emitter set will always be inserted whether you press <%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> or <%10><%2>SHIFT + INSERT<%3><%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Build default set<%3>
Pressing this button opens a new 'sub leaf' in which you can define the default emitter set.
Key.English:
<%2>Build default set<%3>
Pressing this button opens a new 'sub leaf' in which you can define the default emitter set.

Key.Original:
<%2>Default emitter set<%3>
Defining the default emitter set is quite simple, you can define:
%1Active emitters (amount)
%1Emitter type
%1Effect type
%1Effect
Key.English:
<%2>Default emitter set<%3>
Defining the default emitter set is quite simple, you can define:
%1Active emitters (amount)
%1Emitter type
%1Effect type
%1Effect

Key.Original:
This toggles whether the emitter is to be used in the set or not.
Obviously:
%1Checked = used
%1Not checked = not used
Key.English:
This toggles whether the emitter is to be used in the set or not.
Obviously:
%1Checked = used
%1Not checked = not used

Key.Original:
From this you select the type of emitter to use for this emitter.
Choices are of course:
%1Particle
%1Light
Key.English:
From this you select the type of emitter to use for this emitter.
Choices are of course:
%1Particle
%1Light

Key.Original:
From this you select the type of the effect for this emitter.
Choices are:
%1Class
A CfgCloudlets/CfgLights class from the config

%1Preset
A particle/light preset saved with the tool

%1Emitter
Any emitter you have placed.
When this is selected the parameters of that emitter will be used for this default set emitter.
This overrides the emitter type selection if they mismatch, you obviously can not use light params for particle emitter and vice versa..
Key.English:
From this you select the type of the effect for this emitter.
Choices are:
%1Class
A CfgCloudlets/CfgLights class from the config

%1Preset
A particle/light preset saved with the tool

%1Emitter
Any emitter you have placed.
When this is selected the parameters of that emitter will be used for this default set emitter.
This overrides the emitter type selection if they mismatch, you obviously can not use light params for particle emitter and vice versa..

Key.Original:
From this you select either class or preset to use, depending on your previous choices.

You can save whole sets as presets so any preset that has more than one emitter in it will be colored red in this list.

Selecting a red colored preset will 'insert' the whole preset into the default set.
If the preset is larger than 4 emitters the first 4 of that preset will be applied into the default set.
Key.English:
From this you select either class or preset to use, depending on your previous choices.

You can save whole sets as presets so any preset that has more than one emitter in it will be colored red in this list.

Selecting a red colored preset will 'insert' the whole preset into the default set.
If the preset is larger than 4 emitters the first 4 of that preset will be applied into the default set.

Key.Original:
Pressing <%2>OK<%3> will confirm the selections you made as default set and return to the <%2>Prefs<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>
Key.English:
Pressing <%2>OK<%3> will confirm the selections you made as default set and return to the <%2>Prefs<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
Pressing <%2>CANCEL<%3> will discard the selections you made and return to the <%2>Prefs<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>
Key.English:
Pressing <%2>CANCEL<%3> will discard the selections you made and return to the <%2>Prefs<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
Back to <%2>Prefs<%3> leaf.
Checking this disables the data validation on the UI parameter fields. You will get a prompt asking you to make sure you want to do this.
Key.English:
Back to <%2>Prefs<%3> leaf.
Checking this disables the data validation on the UI parameter fields. You will get a prompt asking you to make sure you want to do this.

Key.Original:
Checking this disables the Surface snapping 'slavery'.
Meaning a feature of the tool: when dragging emitters with Eden Surface Snapping on the emitters will follow object surfaces they are dragged over.
Checking this box will disable that feature.
Key.English:
Checking this disables the Surface snapping 'slavery'.
Meaning a feature of the tool: when dragging emitters with Eden Surface Snapping on the emitters will follow object surfaces they are dragged over.
Checking this box will disable that feature.

Key.Original:
Disables hiding the tool UI with Eden UI when hiding it by pressing <%10><%2>BACKSPACE<%3><%3>.
When this box NOT ticked the tool UI will hide with the Eden UI, and vice versa.
Key.English:
Disables hiding the tool UI with Eden UI when hiding it by pressing <%10><%2>BACKSPACE<%3><%3>.
When this box NOT ticked the tool UI will hide with the Eden UI, and vice versa.

Key.Original:
Enables 'Eden auto-dodging' feature.
Means that when this is enabled the tool UI will automatically fade out/in depending on if the mouse cursor is over either of the Eden side panels. This feature can be temporarily disabled by pressing and holding down <%10><%2>CTRL<%3><%3> when entering the side panel areas.
This exists because on some resolutions or UI scales the tool will obstruct the Eden side panels and this enabled you don't need to manually hide or reveal the tool.
Key.English:
Enables 'Eden auto-dodging' feature.
Means that when this is enabled the tool UI will automatically fade out/in depending on if the mouse cursor is over either of the Eden side panels. This feature can be temporarily disabled by pressing and holding down <%10><%2>CTRL<%3><%3> when entering the side panel areas.
This exists because on some resolutions or UI scales the tool will obstruct the Eden side panels and this enabled you don't need to manually hide or reveal the tool.

Key.Original: <%2>Defaults button<%3> will reset the preferences to 'factory defaults'.
Key.English: <%2>Defaults button<%3> will reset the preferences to 'factory defaults'.

Key.Original: <%2>OK Pop-ups button<%3> will re-enable all pop-up messages disabled with 'Don't show this message again'.
Key.English: <%2>OK Pop-ups button<%3> will re-enable all pop-up messages disabled with 'Don't show this message again'.

Key.Original:
<%2>Revert button<%3> is a sort of a Hail Mary pass if something goes awry with the tool. Something going awry means a visible scripting error popping up which in very high likelihood means that things are FUBAR.
Pressing this button erases everything done with this tool from the current scenario saving it from doom..
Key.English:
<%2>Revert button<%3> is a sort of a Hail Mary pass if something goes awry with the tool. Something going awry means a visible scripting error popping up which in very high likelihood means that things are FUBAR.
Pressing this button erases everything done with this tool from the current scenario saving it from doom..

Key.Original: Particle Editor: Basic Params Leaf
Key.English: Particle Editor: Basic Params Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Basic Params<%3>

This is where you can edit most of the parameters you would normally set for your emitter with <%10>setParticleParams<%3>
This is just a shortish overview of the different parameters, for more in-depth information and examples refer to the emitter editor manual.
For basic understanding of the particle parameters refer to BIS Wiki.
Key.English:
<%2>Basic Params<%3>

This is where you can edit most of the parameters you would normally set for your emitter with <%10>setParticleParams<%3>
This is just a shortish overview of the different parameters, for more in-depth information and examples refer to the emitter editor manual.
For basic understanding of the particle parameters refer to BIS Wiki.

Key.Original:
<%2>Sprite<%3>

Sprite is particle model that is used for the given particle class/effect.
This also determines the texture used for the particle. Particles are basically a step-animation using a texture which has 'still images' (frames) of the effect, so for example for fire there's different phases of a flame.
Funnily enough there isn't really any too user-friednly way to actually know what texture the sprite uses nor previewing that texture....
Key.English:
<%2>Sprite<%3>

Sprite is particle model that is used for the given particle class/effect.
This also determines the texture used for the particle. Particles are basically a step-animation using a texture which has 'still images' (frames) of the effect, so for example for fire there's different phases of a flame.
Funnily enough there isn't really any too user-friednly way to actually know what texture the sprite uses nor previewing that texture....

Key.Original:
<%2>Type<%3>

Type kind of particle to use, either
%1'Billboard' (2D sprite) which is used for most particle effects
%1'Space Object' which is a 3D particle, used to create things like flies and such.
Key.English:
<%2>Type<%3>

Type kind of particle to use, either
%1'Billboard' (2D sprite) which is used for most particle effects
%1'Space Object' which is a 3D particle, used to create things like flies and such.

Key.Original:
<%2>nTieth<%3>

A coefficient of the texture size (used by the sprite), in pixels: 2048/coef
Key.English:
<%2>nTieth<%3>

A coefficient of the texture size (used by the sprite), in pixels: 2048/coef

Key.Original:
<%2>FSIndex<%3>

The index (number) of the horizontal row of frames in the texture used by the sprite.
The index number starts from 0 (zero) like with arrays, so 0 is the topmost row, 1 is the next down..
Key.English:
<%2>FSIndex<%3>

The index (number) of the horizontal row of frames in the texture used by the sprite.
The index number starts from 0 (zero) like with arrays, so 0 is the topmost row, 1 is the next down..

Key.Original:
<%2>Count<%3>

The amount of frames to play starting from the given row of frames (defined in <%10>FSIndex<%3>).
The amount of frames that are feasible to play depend on the texture the sprite uses.
Key.English:
<%2>Count<%3>

The amount of frames to play starting from the given row of frames (defined in <%10>FSIndex<%3>).
The amount of frames that are feasible to play depend on the texture the sprite uses.

Key.Original:
<%2>Loop<%3>

Loop toggle for the particle animation, as in if the particle is still alive and the count of frames is reached (defined in <%10>Count<%3>) it will start over and will keep playing though the count of frames until the particle dies.
Key.English:
<%2>Loop<%3>

Loop toggle for the particle animation, as in if the particle is still alive and the count of frames is reached (defined in <%10>Count<%3>) it will start over and will keep playing though the count of frames until the particle dies.

Key.Original:
<%2>Timer Period<%3>

Interval in which a <%10>onTimer<%3> event (explained later) is called. Time in seconds.
Key.English:
<%2>Timer Period<%3>

Interval in which a <%10>onTimer<%3> event (explained later) is called. Time in seconds.

Key.Original:
<%2>Lifetime<%3>

Time in seconds after which the particle is deleted.
Key.English:
<%2>Lifetime<%3>

Time in seconds after which the particle is deleted.

Key.Original:
<%2>Position<%3>

Position3D. Position relative to the emitter itself, or if the emitter is attached to something position relative to the object it is attached to.
Key.English:
<%2>Position<%3>

Position3D. Position relative to the emitter itself, or if the emitter is attached to something position relative to the object it is attached to.

Key.Original:
<%2>Move velocity<%3>

Velocity vector for the particle, [x, y, z]. As in direction and speed of movement in 3D space.
Key.English:
<%2>Move velocity<%3>

Velocity vector for the particle, [x, y, z]. As in direction and speed of movement in 3D space.

Key.Original:
<%2>Rotation velocity<%3>

A float number, how many rotations particle spins per second.
Key.English:
<%2>Rotation velocity<%3>

A float number, how many rotations particle spins per second.

Key.Original:
<%2>Random direction intensity<%3>

A value which is added to each move velocity vector element. It's a value randomly picked between 0 and the value entered here.
Key.English:
<%2>Random direction intensity<%3>

A value which is added to each move velocity vector element. It's a value randomly picked between 0 and the value entered here.

Key.Original:
<%2>Random direction period<%3>

Interval, in seconds, in which the <%10>Random direction intensity<%3> change of the move velocity vector happens.
Key.English:
<%2>Random direction period<%3>

Interval, in seconds, in which the <%10>Random direction intensity<%3> change of the move velocity vector happens.

Key.Original:
<%2>Weight<%3>

Mass of the particle, in kilograms. This value is a part of the physics equations to determine whether the particle is denser than the surrounding air.
Works with <%10>Volume<%3>, so <%10>particle density = weight/volume<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Weight<%3>

Mass of the particle, in kilograms. This value is a part of the physics equations to determine whether the particle is denser than the surrounding air.
Works with <%10>Volume<%3>, so <%10>particle density = weight/volume<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Volume<%3>

Volume of the particle, in cubic meters. Works with <%10>Weight<%3>, so <%10>particle density = weight/volume<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Volume<%3>

Volume of the particle, in cubic meters. Works with <%10>Weight<%3>, so <%10>particle density = weight/volume<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Friction<%3>

Determines how much air friction the particle has, the higher the value the more friction and thus the harder for the particle to travel through the air. Affects the speed travelling of the particle.
Key.English:
<%2>Friction<%3>

Determines how much air friction the particle has, the higher the value the more friction and thus the harder for the particle to travel through the air. Affects the speed travelling of the particle.

Key.Original:
<%2>onTimer script<%3>

Path to a script file to run on <%2>onTimer<%3> event, interval determined by <%10>TimerPeriod<%3>. The particle's position is passed into the executed script, can be obtained with <%10>_this<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>onTimer script<%3>

Path to a script file to run on <%2>onTimer<%3> event, interval determined by <%10>TimerPeriod<%3>. The particle's position is passed into the executed script, can be obtained with <%10>_this<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>beforeDestroy script<%3>

Path to a script file that is run just before the particle dies. The particle's position is passed into the executed script, can be obtained with <%10>_this<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>beforeDestroy script<%3>

Path to a script file that is run just before the particle dies. The particle's position is passed into the executed script, can be obtained with <%10>_this<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Attached to<%3>

Tool specific parameter, when the emitter is attached to some entity shows the entity (object referer).
Key.English:
<%2>Attached to<%3>

Tool specific parameter, when the emitter is attached to some entity shows the entity (object referer).

Key.Original:
<%2>Selection<%3>

Tool specific parameter, if the emitter is attached to some model selection on the entity model it is attached to, shows the selection name.
Key.English:
<%2>Selection<%3>

Tool specific parameter, if the emitter is attached to some model selection on the entity model it is attached to, shows the selection name.

Key.Original:
<%2>Angle<%3>

Determines the starting angle of the particle (presumably this is related to the <%10>Space Object<%2> type particle)
Key.English:
<%2>Angle<%3>

Determines the starting angle of the particle (presumably this is related to the <%10>Space Object<%2> type particle)

Key.Original:
<%2>onSurface<%3>

Determines whether the particle is placed on (water) surface on start of it's existence, default value is true, works only if <%10>circleRadius<%2> > 0 (<%10>circleRadius<%20> is define in the <%10>Circle<%30> leaf)
Key.English:
<%2>onSurface<%3>

Determines whether the particle is placed on (water) surface on start of it's existence, default value is true, works only if <%10>circleRadius<%2> > 0 (<%10>circleRadius<%20> is define in the <%10>Circle<%30> leaf)

Key.Original:
<%2>bounceOnSurface<%3>

Speed loss coefficient when particle collides with the ground. Collision value can be between 0 and 1, -1 to disable collision. Collision disabled by default. Very performance hungry so should be used with care.
Key.English:
<%2>bounceOnSurface<%3>

Speed loss coefficient when particle collides with the ground. Collision value can be between 0 and 1, -1 to disable collision. Collision disabled by default. Very performance hungry so should be used with care.

Key.Original:
<%2>drop interval<%3>

The interval in which a new particle is emitted from the emitter. Time in seconds.
Key.English:
<%2>drop interval<%3>

The interval in which a new particle is emitted from the emitter. Time in seconds.

Done.

Key.English:
Done.

Key.Original: Particle Editor: Render Params Leaf
Key.English: Particle Editor: Render Params Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Render Params<%3>

This is where you can edit the rest of the parameters you would normally set for your emitter with <%10>setParticleParams<%3> that were not covered in <%10>Basic Params.<%3>
Here you can finalize the animation of the particle.
Key.English:
<%2>Render Params<%3>

This is where you can edit the rest of the parameters you would normally set for your emitter with <%10>setParticleParams<%3> that were not covered in <%10>Basic Params.<%3>
Here you can finalize the animation of the particle.

Key.Original:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

'Handles' the frames of the animation.
This shows the current selected frame number.
Key.English:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

'Handles' the frames of the animation.
This shows the current selected frame number.

Key.Original:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

This shows the total amount of frames in the animation.
Key.English:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

This shows the total amount of frames in the animation.

Key.Original:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

With the %11 and %12 buttons you can scroll through the frames:
%1%10 = Previous frame
%1%11 = Next frame
Key.English:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

With the %11 and %12 buttons you can scroll through the frames:
%1%10 = Previous frame
%1%11 = Next frame

Key.Original:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

With the - and + buttons you can add and remove frames, self explanatory:
%1+ adds frame
%1- removes frame
NOTE that frames are always added to and removed from the end of the frame list.
Key.English:
<%2>Frame nr.<%3>

With the - and + buttons you can add and remove frames, self explanatory:
%1+ adds frame
%1- removes frame
NOTE that frames are always added to and removed from the end of the frame list.

Key.Original:
<%2>Scale<%3>

Size of the particle in the given animation frame. In meters.
Key.English:
<%2>Scale<%3>

Size of the particle in the given animation frame. In meters.

Key.Original:
<%2>Anim speed<%3>

How fast the frame is 'passed through'; according to the BIKI 'number of animation cycles in 1s'.
So speed is kinda the FPS for the animation. The higher the value the faster the speed of course.
Key.English:
<%2>Anim speed<%3>

How fast the frame is 'passed through'; according to the BIKI 'number of animation cycles in 1s'.
So speed is kinda the FPS for the animation. The higher the value the faster the speed of course.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This checkbox toggles the <%2>particle main color<%3> as the color to edit with the sliders.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This checkbox toggles the <%2>particle main color<%3> as the color to edit with the sliders.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows the color array produced by the sliders.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows the color array produced by the sliders.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This checkbox toggles the <%2>emissive color<%3> as the color to edit with the sliders.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This checkbox toggles the <%2>emissive color<%3> as the color to edit with the sliders.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows the emissive color array produced by the sliders.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows the emissive color array produced by the sliders.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows which of the colors is being edited by the sliders, <%10>Color<%3> or <%10>Emissive<%3> color
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows which of the colors is being edited by the sliders, <%10>Color<%3> or <%10>Emissive<%3> color

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows a preview of the edited color.
not necessarily 100% 1:1 with actual color of the particle. Alpha has no effect to this preview.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This shows a preview of the edited color.
not necessarily 100% 1:1 with actual color of the particle. Alpha has no effect to this preview.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color sliders<%3>

Color is 'format' RGBA:
%1R = Red
%1G = Green
%1B = Blue
%1A = Alpha (transparency)/Luminance
Key.English:
<%2>Color sliders<%3>

Color is 'format' RGBA:
%1R = Red
%1G = Green
%1B = Blue
%1A = Alpha (transparency)/Luminance

Key.Original:
<%2>Luminance<%3>

Luminance toggle, luminance determines how visible the particle is in Night Vision and Thermal Imaging.
Switches the alpha channel slider between alpha and luminance. On particles a negative value as alpha translates to particle luminance value, the lower the number the higher the luminance.
In NV the effect is really subtle though, depending on the color of the particle (lighter particle shows this effect a little better). The range of the slider is from -0.1 to -10, beyond that there seems to be no visual difference.
Key.English:
<%2>Luminance<%3>

Luminance toggle, luminance determines how visible the particle is in Night Vision and Thermal Imaging.
Switches the alpha channel slider between alpha and luminance. On particles a negative value as alpha translates to particle luminance value, the lower the number the higher the luminance.
In NV the effect is really subtle though, depending on the color of the particle (lighter particle shows this effect a little better). The range of the slider is from -0.1 to -10, beyond that there seems to be no visual difference.

Key.Original:
<%2>Presets<%3>

This is the list of color presets, in addition to a few 'factory presets' it will list any preset you might save.
Key.English:
<%2>Presets<%3>

This is the list of color presets, in addition to a few 'factory presets' it will list any preset you might save.

Key.Original:
<%2>Presets<%3>

<%2>Save Preset button<%3> opens a 'sub-leaf' in which you can save a color as a preset.
Key.English:
<%2>Presets<%3>

<%2>Save Preset button<%3> opens a 'sub-leaf' in which you can save a color as a preset.

Key.Original:
<%2>Saving Color Preset<%3>

Name field for the preset. Do not use any other special characters than underscore, or any non-english alphabet letters.
Key.English:
<%2>Saving Color Preset<%3>

Name field for the preset. Do not use any other special characters than underscore, or any non-english alphabet letters.

Key.Original:
<%2>Saving Color Preset<%3>

<%2>Save preset button<%3> saves the preset.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Saving Color Preset<%3>

<%2>Save preset button<%3> saves the preset.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Saving Color Preset<%3>

<%2>Back button<%3> returns to the <%10>Render Params<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Saving Color Preset<%3>

<%2>Back button<%3> returns to the <%10>Render Params<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Presets<%3>

<%2>Del Preset button<%3> deletes the currently selected preset in the list.
Note that 'factory presets' can not be deleted.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>DELETE<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Presets<%3>

<%2>Del Preset button<%3> deletes the currently selected preset in the list.
Note that 'factory presets' can not be deleted.

Key.Original: Particle Editor: Random Leaf
Key.English: Particle Editor: Random Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Random<%3>

This is where you can edit the parameters you would normally set with setParticleRandom.
Key.English:
<%2>Random<%3>

This is where you can edit the parameters you would normally set with setParticleRandom.

Key.Original:
<%2>Lifetime<%3>

An interpolation between the lifetime value in <%10>Basic Params<%3> and this. In other words the lifetime of the emitted single particle is randomized between basic lifetime and this random lifetime.
Key.English:
<%2>Lifetime<%3>

An interpolation between the lifetime value in <%10>Basic Params<%3> and this. In other words the lifetime of the emitted single particle is randomized between basic lifetime and this random lifetime.

Key.Original:
<%2>Position<%3>

A randomized position between the <%10>Basic Params<%3> position and this. Each vector element is randomized individually.
Key.English:
<%2>Position<%3>

A randomized position between the <%10>Basic Params<%3> position and this. Each vector element is randomized individually.

Key.Original:
<%2>Move velocity<%3>

Randomized move velocity vector between <%10>Basic Params<%3> move velocity and this. Each vector element is randomized individually.
Key.English:
<%2>Move velocity<%3>

Randomized move velocity vector between <%10>Basic Params<%3> move velocity and this. Each vector element is randomized individually.

Key.Original:
<%2>Rotation velocity<%3>

Rotation speed randomizer value, randomized between the <%10>Basic Params<%3> rotation velocity and this. Each vector element is randomized individually.
Key.English:
<%2>Rotation velocity<%3>

Rotation speed randomizer value, randomized between the <%10>Basic Params<%3> rotation velocity and this. Each vector element is randomized individually.

Key.Original:
<%2>Scale<%3>

Randomizer for the particle size, interpolates a value between this and the one in <%10>Render Params<%3> leaf.
Key.English:
<%2>Scale<%3>

Randomizer for the particle size, interpolates a value between this and the one in <%10>Render Params<%3> leaf.

Key.Original:
<%2>Random direction intensity<%3>

Randomizer value for <&10>Rand. Direction Intensity<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Random direction intensity<%3>

Randomizer value for <&10>Rand. Direction Intensity<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Random direction period<%3>

Randomizer value for <&10>Rand. Direction Period<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Random direction period<%3>

Randomizer value for <&10>Rand. Direction Period<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Angle<%3>

Randomizer value for <&10>Angle<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Angle<%3>

Randomizer value for <&10>Angle<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This randomizes the color between this and the color defined in <%10>Render Params<%3>
Color is of course of the same type RGBA. In <%10>Render Params<%3> you can set the color for each animation frame separately so this randomization will apply to all frames.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

Color is of course of the same type RGBA. In <%10>Render Params<%3> you can set the color for each animation frame separately so this randomization will apply to all frames.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This is the color preview for the sliders. Alpha has no effect to this preview.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This is the color preview for the sliders. Alpha has no effect to this preview.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

This is the color array output for the sliders.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

This is the color array output for the sliders.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

Sliders to set the color with.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

Sliders to set the color with.

Key.Original:
<%2>bounceOnSurface<%3>

Randomizer value for <%10>bounceOnSurface<%3>, interpolates a random value between this and the one defined in <%10>Basic Params<%3>.

Key.Original: Particle Editor: Circle Leaf
Key.English: Particle Editor: Circle Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Circle<%3>

This is where you can edit the parameters you would normally set with <%10>setParticleCircle<%3>.
Only two params so short and sweet.
Key.English:
<%2>Circle<%3>

This is where you can edit the parameters you would normally set with <%10>setParticleCircle<%3>.
Only two params so short and sweet.

Key.Original:
<%2>Radius<%3>

The radius of the circle created on the emitter position, in meters. The circle center is the emitter position.
NOTE that radius of 5m equals to a diameter of 10m.
The particles will be emitted on the entire circumference of the circle disc, so basically this creates a circular shape emitting particles on it's 'edges'.
Key.English:
<%2>Radius<%3>

The radius of the circle created on the emitter position, in meters. The circle center is the emitter position.
NOTE that radius of 5m equals to a diameter of 10m.
The particles will be emitted on the entire circumference of the circle disc, so basically this creates a circular shape emitting particles on it's 'edges'.

Key.Original:
<%2>Velocity<%3>

Velocity vector along the circle disc defined with <%10>Radius<%3>. Velocity is transformed and added to total velocity determined by the move velocity in <%10>Basic Params<%3> and <%10>Random<%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Velocity<%3>

Velocity vector along the circle disc defined with <%10>Radius<%3>. Velocity is transformed and added to total velocity determined by the move velocity in <%10>Basic Params<%3> and <%10>Random<%3>

Done.

This is where you can edit the parameters you would normally set with <%10>setParticleFire<%3>.

<%2>Damage<%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Damage type<%3>

Type of the damage inflicted. The game currently only offers <%10>Fire<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Damage type<%3>

Type of the damage inflicted. The game currently only offers <%10>Fire<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Core intensity<%3>

Damage intensity in emitter center (position). Seems to be some sort of coefficient of some value determined in the damage type somewhere in the bowels of the game engine.
Key.English:
<%2>Core intensity<%3>

Damage intensity in emitter center (position). Seems to be some sort of coefficient of some value determined in the damage type somewhere in the bowels of the game engine.

Key.Original:
<%2>Core distance<%3>

Distance how far from the emitter center to receive the damage defined by <%10>core intensity<%3>. In meters.
Key.English:
<%2>Core distance<%3>

Distance how far from the emitter center to receive the damage defined by <%10>core intensity<%3>. In meters.

<%2>damage time<%3>

Damage inflicting interval, within 1 second. 1 means once a second, 0.5 two times a second and so on...
Key.English:
<%2>damage time<%3>

Damage inflicting interval, within 1 second. 1 means once a second, 0.5 two times a second and so on...

Key.Original: Particle Editor: Special Leaf
Key.English: Particle Editor: Special Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Special<%3>

This is where you can edit some parameters that have no vanilla behaviour in form of a scripting command.
Key.English:
<%2>Special<%3>

This is where you can edit some parameters that have no vanilla behaviour in form of a scripting command.

Key.Original:
<%2>Die out<%3>

A timer, in seconds, after which the currently selected emitter or emitter set will be deleted.
Timer starts after the emitters start emitting in scenario runtime.
Key.English:
<%2>Die out<%3>

A timer, in seconds, after which the currently selected emitter or emitter set will be deleted.
Timer starts after the emitters start emitting in scenario runtime.

Key.Original:
<%2>Follow objectHide<%3>

Toggles whether the selected emitter or emitter set will follow the objectHide status of the object it's attached to.
Means that if this is NOT toggled emitters attached to an object that is set to <%10>hideObject true<%3> in scenario runtime will not hide with the object.

Might seem odd to have this optional but this starts a looping script for each object so for performance's sake this is optional, no need to use if you know hideObject will not be used.
Key.English:
<%2>Follow objectHide<%3>

Toggles whether the selected emitter or emitter set will follow the objectHide status of the object it's attached to.
Means that if this is NOT toggled emitters attached to an object that is set to <%10>hideObject true<%3> in scenario runtime will not hide with the object.

Might seem odd to have this optional but this starts a looping script for each object so for performance's sake this is optional, no need to use if you know hideObject will not be used.

Key.Original:
<%2>Importt module(s) button<%3>

If the scenario has <%10>BIS effect module(s)<%3> (fire/smoke) inserted this button will become active and you can import the modules into the tool for editing.
NOTE that the module is replaced with an emitter.
Either imports all modules or just selected ones.
Key.English:
<%2>Importt module(s) button<%3>

If the scenario has <%10>BIS effect module(s)<%3> (fire/smoke) inserted this button will become active and you can import the modules into the tool for editing.
NOTE that the module is replaced with an emitter.
Either imports all modules or just selected ones.

Key.Original:
Done.

<%10>Check out the full documentation<%11>
Key.English:
Done.

Key.Original: Particle Editor: Export/Import Leaf
Key.English: Particle Editor: Export/Import Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Export/Import<%3>

This is basically what the 2D editor era particle editors did, from here you can export particle parameters for pasting into scripts.
NOTE that you don't have to do this, <%2>the effects will appear in-game exactly as they appear in the editor with no scripting needed<%3>. This is just here for convinience.

This leaf also offers other stuff:
%1 Import parameters
%1Save presets
%1Load presets
Key.English:
<%2>Export/Import<%3>

This is basically what the 2D editor era particle editors did, from here you can export particle parameters for pasting into scripts.
NOTE that you don't have to do this, <%2>the effects will appear in-game exactly as they appear in the editor with no scripting needed<%3>. This is just here for convinience.

This leaf also offers other stuff:
%1 Import parameters
%1Save presets
%1Load presets

Key.Original:
<%2>Export<%3>

Each particle related scripting command has it's own data field, calling them <%10>export fields<%3>.
When a particle emitter is selected it's parameters get 'printed' into their respective fields
Key.English:
<%2>Export<%3>

Each particle related scripting command has it's own data field, calling them <%10>export fields<%3>.
When a particle emitter is selected it's parameters get 'printed' into their respective fields

Key.Original:
<%2>Export button<%3>

Pressing the <%10>Eport button<%3> will export the parameters into the clipboard and into the .rpt file.
By default exports the parameters of ALL emitters in the scenario.

To export in config format (config class) hold down <%10><%2>CTRL<%3><%3> and press the Export button. The other settings apply with this as well, export is just in config format.
Key.English:
<%2>Export button<%3>

Pressing the <%10>Eport button<%3> will export the parameters into the clipboard and into the .rpt file.
By default exports the parameters of ALL emitters in the scenario.

To export in config format (config class) hold down <%10><%2>CTRL<%3><%3> and press the Export button. The other settings apply with this as well, export is just in config format.

Key.Original:
<%2>Export current only<%3>

Checking this will limit the exporting to only the currently shown parameters.
Key.English:
<%2>Export current only<%3>

Checking this will limit the exporting to only the currently shown parameters.

Key.Original:
<%2>Exclude light emitters<%3>

Checking this will exclude light emitter params from the export if exporting an emitter set that has a light emitter in it.
Key.English:
<%2>Exclude light emitters<%3>

Checking this will exclude light emitter params from the export if exporting an emitter set that has a light emitter in it.

Key.Original:
<%2>Param 'pages'<%3>

When a set of emitters is selected for export this allows you to 'scroll through' the emitters to view the individual params of each of them.
In case you for example want to export the params of only one of the emitters in the set. Or 'paste' params into one..
Key.English:
<%2>Param 'pages'<%3>

When a set of emitters is selected for export this allows you to 'scroll through' the emitters to view the individual params of each of them.
In case you for example want to export the params of only one of the emitters in the set. Or 'paste' params into one..

Key.Original:
<%2>Lock Export fields<%3>

'Locks' the 'export fields' so that they won't get auto-filled with the export data when selecting emitters. When uncheckd each time you select an emitter it's params along with the scripting commands get populated into the 'export fields.'
Key.English:
<%2>Lock Export fields<%3>

'Locks' the 'export fields' so that they won't get auto-filled with the export data when selecting emitters. When uncheckd each time you select an emitter it's params along with the scripting commands get populated into the 'export fields.'

Key.Original:
<%2>Clear button<%3>

Clears the 'export fields' of all data.
Key.English:
<%2>Clear button<%3>

Clears the 'export fields' of all data.

Key.Original:
<%2>Save Preset button<%3>

Opens up a 'sub-leaf' in which you can save the particle params as presets.
Key.English:
<%2>Save Preset button<%3>

Opens up a 'sub-leaf' in which you can save the particle params as presets.

Key.Original:
<%2>Name<%3>

Here you can save the particle params as a preset.
It obviously requires a name.
Key.English:
<%2>Name<%3>

Here you can save the particle params as a preset.
It obviously requires a name.

Key.Original:
<%2>Description<%3>

You can also give it a optional description. If saving a whole emitter set as a preset it is useful to make a note here on how many emitters the set has, or just some reminder to yourself about the preset.
This description appears as tooltip in the <%10>Load Preset<%3> list when you hover over an item in it.
Key.English:
<%2>Description<%3>

You can also give it a optional description. If saving a whole emitter set as a preset it is useful to make a note here on how many emitters the set has, or just some reminder to yourself about the preset.
This description appears as tooltip in the <%10>Load Preset<%3> list when you hover over an item in it.

Key.Original:
<%2>Save set as preset<%3>

When this is checked and an emitter in a set is selected the whole set is saved as a preset. Otherwise just the emitter that is currently selected is the one getting it's params saved.
Key.English:
<%2>Save set as preset<%3>

When this is checked and an emitter in a set is selected the whole set is saved as a preset. Otherwise just the emitter that is currently selected is the one getting it's params saved.

Key.Original:
<%2>Save Button<%3>

Saves the params as a preset with the given name.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Save Button<%3>

Saves the params as a preset with the given name.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Back Button<%3>

Returns to the Export/Import leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Back Button<%3>

Returns to the Export/Import leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Load Preset<%3>

Opens up a 'sub-leaf' to load particle presets.
Key.English:
<%2>Load Preset<%3>

Opens up a 'sub-leaf' to load particle presets.

Key.Original:
<%2>Load Preset<%3>

Here you can load particle param presets you have saved, listed in this list.
Presets with more than one emitter will appear in <%10>red<%3>.
Key.English:
<%2>Load Preset<%3>

Here you can load particle param presets you have saved, listed in this list.
Presets with more than one emitter will appear in <%10>red<%3>.

Key.Original:
<%2>Load button<%3>

'Injects' the selected preset into the currently selected emitter or emitter set (depends on the preset 'size').
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Load button<%3>

'Injects' the selected preset into the currently selected emitter or emitter set (depends on the preset 'size').
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Delete button<%3>

Deletes the selected preset from the preset list, permanently.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>DELETE<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Delete button<%3>

Deletes the selected preset from the preset list, permanently.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>DELETE<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Back button<%3>

Returns back to <%10>Export/Import<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Back button<%3>

Returns back to <%10>Export/Import<%3> leaf.
Keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Paste Params button<%3>

The naming of the buttons is a tad sucky, but this button 'injects' the parameters visible in the <%10>export fields<%3> into the currently selected emitter.
So, with this you can 'import' particle effects you may have previously done in your scripts by copying the parameters into their respective fields, selecting an emitter and pressing this <%10>Paste Params<%3> button.
Key.English:
<%2>Paste Params button<%3>

The naming of the buttons is a tad sucky, but this button 'injects' the parameters visible in the <%10>export fields<%3> into the currently selected emitter.
So, with this you can 'import' particle effects you may have previously done in your scripts by copying the parameters into their respective fields, selecting an emitter and pressing this <%10>Paste Params<%3> button.

Key.Original:
Done.

<%10>Check out the full documentation<%11>
Key.English:
Done.

<%10>Check out the full documentation<%11>

Key.Original: Light Editor: Light Params Leaf
Key.English: Light Editor: Light Params Leaf

Key.Original:
<%2>Light Params<%3>

This is where you define all the parameters you would normally apply via the setLightXXXX scripting commands.
Key.English:
<%2>Light Params<%3>

This is where you define all the parameters you would normally apply via the setLightXXXX scripting commands.

Key.Original:
<%2>Color<%3>

Main color of the light, color format RGB.
Key.English:
<%2>Color<%3>

Main color of the light, color format RGB.

Key.Original:
<%2>Ambient color<%3>

Ambient color of the light, color format RGB.
Ambient color means the color that will light up the surroundings of the light, even surfaces that are not facing the light.
Key.English:
<%2>Ambient color<%3>

Ambient color of the light, color format RGB.
Ambient color means the color that will light up the surroundings of the light, even surfaces that are not facing the light.

Key.Original:
<%2>Link ambient with color<%3>

Toggling this makes the ambient color 'follow' the main color sliders.
Key.English:
<%2>Link ambient with color<%3>

Toggling this makes the ambient color 'follow' the main color sliders.

Key.Original:
<%2>Intensity<%3>

The brightness of the light. The numbers with this are quite big, start with at least 1000
Key.English:
<%2>Intensity<%3>

The brightness of the light. The numbers with this are quite big, start with at least 1000

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation<%3>

Light attenuation, if the term is a bit vague it means light intensity drop-off over distance.
Standard method of attenuation (1 / (constant + linear*dist + quadratic*dist*dist)). Start param represents distance, where the attenuation starts to take effects (dist = distance - start)
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation<%3>

Light attenuation, if the term is a bit vague it means light intensity drop-off over distance.
Standard method of attenuation (1 / (constant + linear*dist + quadratic*dist*dist)). Start param represents distance, where the attenuation starts to take effects (dist = distance - start)

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation - Start<%3>

Distance from the light after which the light attenuation starts. In meters.
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation - Start<%3>

Distance from the light after which the light attenuation starts. In meters.

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation - Constant<%3>

Constant attenuation coef.
(1 / (constant + linear * dist + quadratic * dist * dist))
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation - Constant<%3>

Constant attenuation coef.
(1 / (constant + linear * dist + quadratic * dist * dist))

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation - Linear<%3>

Linear attenuation coef.
(1 / (constant + linear * dist + quadratic * dist * dist))
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation - Linear<%3>

Linear attenuation coef.
(1 / (constant + linear * dist + quadratic * dist * dist))

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation - Quadratic<%3>

Quadratic attenuation coef.
(1 / (constant + linear * dist + quadratic * dist * dist))
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation - Quadratic<%3>

Quadratic attenuation coef.
(1 / (constant + linear * dist + quadratic * dist * dist))

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation - Hardlimit start<%3>

Optional, max distance hard limit start (start of fading of intensity to 0) in m
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation - Hardlimit start<%3>

Optional, max distance hard limit start (start of fading of intensity to 0) in m

Key.Original:
<%2>Attenuation - Hardlimit end<%3>

Optional, max distance hard limit end (end of fading of intensity to 0) in m
Key.English:
<%2>Attenuation - Hardlimit end<%3>

Optional, max distance hard limit end (end of fading of intensity to 0) in m

Key.Original:
<%2>Position<%3>

Position3D. Position relative to the emitter itself, or if the emitter is attached to something position relative to the object it is attached to.
Key.English:
<%2>Position<%3>

Position3D. Position relative to the emitter itself, or if the emitter is attached to something position relative to the object it is attached to.

Key.Original:
<%2>Use flare<%3>

Toggle flare on/off. Flare is the 'star' shaped effect on the light source.
Key.English:
<%2>Use flare<%3>

Toggle flare on/off. Flare is the 'star' shaped effect on the light source.

Key.Original:
<%2>Flare size<%3>

Size of the flare effect, in meters.
Key.English:
<%2>Flare size<%3>

Size of the flare effect, in meters.

Key.Original:
<%2>Flare max distance<%3>

Maximum distance the flare effect is visible to, in meters.
Key.English:
<%2>Flare max distance<%3>

Maximum distance the flare effect is visible to, in meters.

Key.Original:
<%2>Visible in daylight<%3>

Toggle daytime visibility on/off.
Key.English:
<%2>Visible in daylight<%3>

Toggle daytime visibility on/off.

Key.Original:
<%2>Attached to<%3>

The object the light is attached to (object referer)
Key.English:
<%2>Attached to<%3>

The object the light is attached to (object referer)

Key.Original:
<%2>Selection<%3>

The selection name the light is attached to on the object, if any.
Key.English:
<%2>Selection<%3>

The selection name the light is attached to on the object, if any.

Key.Original:
<%2>Die out<%3>

Die out timer since the light started to emit, in seconds, after which the light emitters is deleted.
Key.English:
<%2>Die out<%3>

Die out timer since the light started to emit, in seconds, after which the light emitters is deleted.

Key.Original:
<%2>Follow objectHide<%3>

Toggles whether the selected light emitter will follow the objectHide status of the object it's attached to.
Means that if this is NOT toggled emitter attached to an object that is set to <%10>hideObject true<%3> in scenario runtime will not hide with the object.

Might seem odd to have this optional but this starts a looping script for each object so for performance's sake this is optional, no need to use if you know hideObject will not be used.
Key.English:
