Key.Original: Keyboard shortcuts
Key.English: Keyboard shortcuts

Key.Original:
<%2>KEYBOARD SHORTCUTS<%3>

<%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + E<%3><%3>- Launch the tool

<%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> - place down an emitter
<%10><%2>SHIFT + INSERT<%3><%3> - place down the default emitter set (if toggled in prefs)

<%10><%2>SHIFT + A<%3><%3> - Select attach mode
<%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3> - Attach emitter(s) to object
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + A<%3><%3> - Attach dragged emitter(s) to object
<%10><%2>SHIFT + CTRL + C<%3><%3> - Clone selected emitter
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + D<%3><%3> - Disable/enable all emitters emitting in Eden
<%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + D<%3><%3> - Disable/enable selected emitter(s) from emitting in Eden
<%10><%2>ALT + G<%3><%3> - Group emitter into a set with other emitter(s)
<%10><%2>ALT + Q<%3><%3> - Select next emitter in the list
<%10><%2>ALT + Z<%3><%3> - select previous emitter in the list
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + R<%3><%3> - Rename selected emitter
<%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3> - Synchronize trigger with emitter(s)
<%10><%2>ALT + F1<%3><%3> - Switch to Particle editor
<%10><%2>ALT + F2<%3><%3> - Switch to Light editor

<%10><%2>CTRL + 1...8<%3><%3> - Select main menu leaf
<%10><%2>CTRL + HOME<%3><%3> - Move camera to selected emitter
<%10><%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3><%3> - Hide/show tool UI
<%10><%2>CTRL + ESC<%3><%3> - Shutdown tool
<%10><%2>ALT + D<%3><%3> - Disable/enable all emitter(s) from emitting in Eden
<%10><%2>T<%3><%3> - Hold down T for terrain object highlighting

<%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + WINDOWS KEY<%3><%3> - Show selected sprite texture
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + WINDOWS KEY<%3><%3> - Hide shown selected sprite texture
Key.English:
<%2>KEYBOARD SHORTCUTS<%3>

<%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + E<%3><%3>- Launch the tool

<%10><%2>INSERT<%3><%3> - place down an emitter
<%10><%2>SHIFT + INSERT<%3><%3> - place down the default emitter set (if toggled in prefs)

<%10><%2>SHIFT + A<%3><%3> - Select attach mode
<%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3> - Attach emitter(s) to object
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + A<%3><%3> - Attach dragged emitter(s) to object
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + C<%3><%3> - Clone selected emitter
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + D<%3><%3> - Disable/enable all emitters emitting in Eden
<%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + D<%3><%3> - Disable/enable selected emitter(s) from emitting in Eden
<%10><%2>ALT + G<%3><%3> - Group emitter into a set with other emitter(s)
<%10><%2>ALT + Q<%3><%3> - Select next emitter in the list
<%10><%2>ALT + Z<%3><%3> - select previous emitter in the list
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + R<%3><%3> - Rename selected emitter
<%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3> - Synchronize trigger with emitter(s)
<%10><%2>ALT + F1<%3><%3> - Switch to Particle editor
<%10><%2>ALT + F2<%3><%3> - Switch to Light editor

<%10><%2>CTRL + 1...8<%3><%3> - Select main menu leaf
<%10><%2>CTRL + HOME<%3><%3> - Move camera to selected emitter
<%10><%2>CTRL + BACKSPACE<%3><%3> - Hide/show tool UI
<%10><%2>CTRL + ESC<%3><%3> - Shutdown tool
<%10><%2>ALT + D<%3><%3> - Disable/enable all emitter(s) from emitting in Eden
<%10><%2>T<%3><%3> - Hold down T for terrain object highlighting

<%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + WINDOWS KEY<%3><%3> - Show selected sprite texture
<%10><%2>SHIFT + ALT + WINDOWS KEY<%3><%3> - Hide shown selected sprite texture

Key.Original: Attaching Emitters
Key.English: Attaching Emitters

Key.Original:
<%2>Attaching Emitters<%3>

This tool features a total of four ways to attach an emitter to an entity or a terrain object. Three of them are 'attach modes' which have to be selected separately before attaching and the fourth exists only as a keyboard shortcut
1. <%2>Basic attach<%3>
2. <%2>Selection Attach<%3>
3. <%2>Global Attach<%3>
4. <%2>'Dragged Attach'<%3> (the shortcut-only method)
Key.English:
<%2>Attaching Emitters<%3>

This tool features a total of four ways to attach an emitter to an entity or a terrain object. Three of them are 'attach modes' which have to be selected separately before attaching and the fourth exists only as a keyboard shortcut
1. <%2>Basic attach<%3>
2. <%2>Selection Attach<%3>
3. <%2>Global Attach<%3>
4. <%2>'Dragged Attach'<%3> (the shortcut-only method)

Key.Original:
<%2>Selecting the attach mode<%3>

Attach mode is selected from the <%2><%10>'Attach mode selector'<%3><%3> button. When you press the button the image on it changes to indicate the current selected attach mode:

Basic Attach
Selection Attach
Global Attach

These attach modes can also be 'cycled' with the keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>SHIFT + A<%3><%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Selecting the attach mode<%3>

Attach mode is selected from the <%2><%10>'Attach mode selector'<%3><%3> button. When you press the button the image on it changes to indicate the current selected attach mode:

Basic Attach
Selection Attach
Global Attach

These attach modes can also be 'cycled' with the keyboard shortcut: <%10><%2>SHIFT + A<%3><%3>

Key.Original:
<%2>Basic Attach<%3>

You could think of it as the same as the basic attachTo scripting command. With this attach mode the emitter will attach to the object position (AGL, in model space of course). The position differs on different object types, on soldier the position is at it's feet, on a chopper it's somewhere in the middle of it's frame, etc.
Key.English:
<%2>Basic Attach<%3>

You could think of it as the same as the basic attachTo scripting command. With this attach mode the emitter will attach to the object position (AGL, in model space of course). The position differs on different object types, on soldier the position is at it's feet, on a chopper it's somewhere in the middle of it's frame, etc.

Key.Original:
How to attach:

While basic attach mode selected select the emitter, hover over the object you wish to attach the emitter to so that the object gets highlighted and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3>

You will hear a sound and the effect moves to the object while the emitter icon is moved to a 'hardcoded' relative position from the object and is connected to the object with a pink 'attach line'.
Key.English:
How to attach:

While basic attach mode selected select the emitter, hover over the object you wish to attach the emitter to so that the object gets highlighted and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3>

You will hear a sound and the effect moves to the object while the emitter icon is moved to a 'hardcoded' relative position from the object and is connected to the object with a pink 'attach line'.

Key.Original:
<%2>Selection Attach<%3>

As the name suggests this attach mode is for attaching the emitter to the object's model selections.
For this to work it of course requires the object model to have selections. Most of them do but for example Props mostly have none.
For terrain objects possible buildingPositions will be included as well.

If trying to attach to an object with no selections a notification message is shown.
Key.English:
<%2>Selection Attach<%3>

As the name suggests this attach mode is for attaching the emitter to the object's model selections.
For this to work it of course requires the object model to have selections. Most of them do but for example Props mostly have none.
For terrain objects possible buildingPositions will be included as well.

If trying to attach to an object with no selections a notification message is shown.

Key.Original:
How to attach:

While selection attach mode selected select the emitter, hover over the object you wish to attach the emitter to so that the object gets highlighted and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3>

A new 'sub-leaf' opens on the tool UI with a list of available model selections on the selected object and the emitter icon is connected to the object with a red line.
When you select a selection from the list you can see how the effect moves to the selected selection position while the emitter icon stays still.

Once selected the selection you want <%2>OK<%3> (or <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>) confirms it. <%2>Cancel<%3> (or <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>) discards the attach and the effect returns to the emitter icon. Also closes the sub-leaf.
Key.English:
How to attach:

While selection attach mode selected select the emitter, hover over the object you wish to attach the emitter to so that the object gets highlighted and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3>

A new 'sub-leaf' opens on the tool UI with a list of available model selections on the selected object and the emitter icon is connected to the object with a red line.
When you select a selection from the list you can see how the effect moves to the selected selection position while the emitter icon stays still.

Once selected the selection you want <%2>OK<%3> (or <%10><%2>ENTER<%3><%3>) confirms it. <%2>Cancel<%3> (or <%10><%2>ESC<%3><%3>) discards the attach and the effect returns to the emitter icon. Also closes the sub-leaf.

Key.Original:
<%2>NOTE:<%3>

Not all of the model selections are necessarily listed on the list because by default only selections that are off of the object position are listed as those selections don't really make sense to list as the Basic Attach attaches to that position.
Also some objects may have several instances of the same selection across different LODs (Level Of Detail) and by default only the first encountered selection is listed.

To list all selections check the box labeled 'Show all selections'.
Key.English:
<%2>NOTE:<%3>

Not all of the model selections are necessarily listed on the list because by default only selections that are off of the object position are listed as those selections don't really make sense to list as the Basic Attach attaches to that position.
Also some objects may have several instances of the same selection across different LODs (Level Of Detail) and by default only the first encountered selection is listed.

To list all selections check the box labeled 'Show all selections'.

Key.Original:
<%2>Global Attach<%3>

This is the most advanced of the attach modes. this allows you to attach the selected emitter to any object anywhere, even inside buildings (on walls, ceiligs etc).
Key.English:
<%2>Global Attach<%3>

This is the most advanced of the attach modes. this allows you to attach the selected emitter to any object anywhere, even inside buildings (on walls, ceiligs etc).

Key.Original:
How to attach:

While global attach mode selected select the emitter and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3>
You will see the emitter move to the camera aim center. Press and hold down the right mouse button and move the mouse around. The emitter will follow where the camera is aiming at.

When satisfied with the position of the emitter press left mouse button to confirm attach (this is also indicated by a sound effect).

To cancel the attach point the camera over empty area and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3> again.
Key.English:
How to attach:

While global attach mode selected select the emitter and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3>
You will see the emitter move to the camera aim center. Press and hold down the right mouse button and move the mouse around. The emitter will follow where the camera is aiming at.

When satisfied with the position of the emitter press left mouse button to confirm attach (this is also indicated by a sound effect).

To cancel the attach point the camera over empty area and press <%10><%2>ALT + A<%3><%3> again.

Key.Original:
<%2>SHIFT + ALT + A<%3>

The last way to attach exists as a kb shortcut only. This requires the Eden Surface snapping enabled. Also the tool preference 'Disable Surface Snap Slavery' should be <%2>unchecked<%3>.

Works only with Eden entities.
Key.English:
<%2>SHIFT + ALT + A<%3>

The last way to attach exists as a kb shortcut only. This requires the Eden Surface snapping enabled. Also the tool preference 'Disable Surface Snap Slavery' should be <%2>unchecked<%3>.

Works only with Eden entities.

Key.Original:
How to attach:

Drag the emitter over some Eden entity. The emitter will follow the entity surfaces like with the Global attach but the difference here is is that this does not work inside buildings and so on.
Once satisfied with the emitter position press <%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + A<%3><%3> and the emitter is attached to the entity on that spot.
Key.English:
How to attach:

Drag the emitter over some Eden entity. The emitter will follow the entity surfaces like with the Global attach but the difference here is is that this does not work inside buildings and so on.
Once satisfied with the emitter position press <%10><%2>CTRL + ALT + A<%3><%3> and the emitter is attached to the entity on that spot.

Key.Original: <%2>NOTE<%3>: All these attach modes are of course available for the light emitters as well, even though this turorial uses just the particle editor for the examples.
Key.English: <%2>NOTE<%3>: All these attach modes are of course available for the light emitters as well, even though this turorial uses just the particle editor for the examples.

Key.Original:
<%2>Attach Finesse<%3>:

The Basic, Global and kb shortcut attach modes can be finetuned by two ways:
1. Adjusting the values in the Position field. Note that the values are in model space.
2. Adjusting the emitter's position with the Translation Widget; activate the widget, select the emitter to adjust, press and hold down <%10><%2>CTRL<%3><%3> on your keyboard → the emitter gets a green “move reticle” indicating it can be move with the widget.
Key.English:
<%2>Attach Finesse<%3>:

The Basic, Global and kb shortcut attach modes can be finetuned by two ways:
1. Adjusting the values in the Position field. Note that the values are in model space.
2. Adjusting the emitter's position with the Translation Widget; activate the widget, select the emitter to adjust, press and hold down <%10><%2>CTRL<%3><%3> on your keyboard → the emitter gets a green “move reticle” indicating it can be move with the widget.

Done.

<%10>Check out the full documentation<%11>
Key.English:
Done.

Key.Original: Interacting with the emitters in-game
Key.English: Interacting with the emitters in-game

Key.Original:
There are a few ways to directly interact 'in-game' (preview/playing exported scenario) with the emitters placed by this tool.
By directly I mean affect the emitters in some way, be it simply deleting them or changing the parameters, or defining when they will start emitting and they will stop.
Key.English:
There are a few ways to directly interact 'in-game' (preview/playing exported scenario) with the emitters placed by this tool.
By directly I mean affect the emitters in some way, be it simply deleting them or changing the parameters, or defining when they will start emitting and they will stop.

Key.Original:
The most simple ones are the two tool parameters that can be found in the tool's <%2>Particle editor 'Special' leaf<%3> and the <%2>Light editor Light Params leaf:<%3>

<%2>- Die out<%3>
<%2>- Follow objectHide<%3>

These were already explained in the respective leaf tutorial sections but repetition is the mother of learning.
Key.English:
The most simple ones are the two tool parameters that can be found in the tool's <%2>Particle editor 'Special' leaf<%3> and the <%2>Light editor Light Params leaf:<%3>

<%2>- Die out<%3>
<%2>- Follow objectHide<%3>

These were already explained in the respective leaf tutorial sections but repetition is the mother of learning.

Key.Original:
<%2>Die out<%3>

This is a timer, in seconds, after which the currently selected emitter/emitter set will be deleted.
Time is measured from the scenario start.
Key.English:
<%2>Die out<%3>

This is a timer, in seconds, after which the currently selected emitter/emitter set will be deleted.
Time is measured from the scenario start.

Key.Original:
<%2>Follow objectHide<%3>

Toggles whether the selected emitter will follow the objectHide status of the object it's attached to.
Means that if this is NOT toggled emitter attached to an object that is set to <%10>hideObject true<%3> in scenario runtime will NOT hide with the object.

Might seem odd to have this optional but this starts a looping script for each object so for performance's sake this is optional, no need to use if you know hideObject will not be used. Looping script is required because there is no eventhandlers for this..

If you're using Dynamic Simulation you may need to enable this if your emitters are attached to objects although the game does already cull particles and lights.
Key.English:
<%2>Follow objectHide<%3>

Toggles whether the selected emitter will follow the objectHide status of the object it's attached to.
Means that if this is NOT toggled emitter attached to an object that is set to <%10>hideObject true<%3> in scenario runtime will NOT hide with the object.

Might seem odd to have this optional but this starts a looping script for each object so for performance's sake this is optional, no need to use if you know hideObject will not be used. Looping script is required because there is no eventhandlers for this..

If you're using Dynamic Simulation you may need to enable this if your emitters are attached to objects although the game does already cull particles and lights.

Key.Original:
There's a third editor based solution for controlling the appearing and disappearing of the emitters: <%2>Triggers.<%3>

Emitter 3Ditor includes a special trigger sync functionality toggled with a specific keyboard shortcut <%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3>.

<%2>NOTE that the regular Eden Sync does NOT activate this feature.<%3>
Key.English:
There's a third editor based solution for controlling the appearing and disappearing of the emitters: <%2>Triggers.<%3>

Emitter 3Ditor includes a special trigger sync functionality toggled with a specific keyboard shortcut <%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3>.

<%2>NOTE that the regular Eden Sync does NOT activate this feature.<%3>

Key.Original:
How it works:

If you sync trigger with an emitter using the kb shortcut <%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3> the trigger will get a special name to identify it by (which you can NOT change) and the emitter will 'follow' the trigger activation:

- If trigger is <%2>not<%3> set to <%10><%2>Repeatable<%3><%3> (activates only once) <%2>the emitter synced to it will start emitting once the trigger is triggered.<%3>
- If the trigger <%2>is<%3> set to <%10><%2>Repeatable<%3><%3> <%2>the emitter synced to it will start emitting when the trigger activates and stop emitting when the trigger deactivates.<%3>

To sync select the emitter you wish to sync with the trigger, hover mouse cursor over the trigger so that it gets highlighted (do NOT select it!) and press <%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3>.
A blue line should appear to indicate sync and the trigger name shown one the Eden entity list should indicate it is now an emitter activator.
Key.English:
How it works:

If you sync trigger with an emitter using the kb shortcut <%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3> the trigger will get a special name to identify it by (which you can NOT change) and the emitter will 'follow' the trigger activation:

- If trigger is <%2>not<%3> set to <%10><%2>Repeatable<%3><%3> (activates only once) <%2>the emitter synced to it will start emitting once the trigger is triggered.<%3>
- If the trigger <%2>is<%3> set to <%10><%2>Repeatable<%3><%3> <%2>the emitter synced to it will start emitting when the trigger activates and stop emitting when the trigger deactivates.<%3>

To sync select the emitter you wish to sync with the trigger, hover mouse cursor over the trigger so that it gets highlighted (do NOT select it!) and press <%10><%2>ALT + S<%3><%3>.
A blue line should appear to indicate sync and the trigger name shown one the Eden entity list should indicate it is now an emitter activator.

Key.Original:
The fourth way to interact with the emitter in scenario runtime is via special functions.
These functions will be available to use in your scenario scripts/functions if you set up them correctly into your scenario file structure.

Where these functions are located depends on your download method:

- if your downloaded the 7z package 'manually' the functions can be found in that package, folder is called <%10><%2>HNEG_eed_scenario_functions<%3><%3>

- if you downloaded from Steam Workshop you will find the <%10><%2>HNEG_eed_scenario_functions<%3><%3> folder in the installation location, which you can access with the game launcher the easiest: in the Mods section click on the Emitter 3Ditor mod - 'show more options' - 'open folder in Windows Explorer'
Key.English:
The fourth way to interact with the emitter in scenario runtime is via special functions.
These functions will be available to use in your scenario scripts/functions if you set up them correctly into your scenario file structure.

Where these functions are located depends on your download method:

- if your downloaded the 7z package 'manually' the functions can be found in that package, folder is called <%10><%2>HNEG_eed_scenario_functions<%3><%3>

- if you downloaded from Steam Workshop you will find the <%10><%2>HNEG_eed_scenario_functions<%3><%3> folder in the installation location, which you can access with the game launcher the easiest: in the Mods section click on the Emitter 3Ditor mod - 'show more options' - 'open folder in Windows Explorer'

Key.Original: For the instructions on how to setup the functions <%10>refer to the Emitter 3Ditor manual<%11> (.pdf) to chapter <%2>IN-GAME FUNCTIONS<%3> (page 94).
Key.English: For the instructions on how to setup the functions <%10>refer to the Emitter 3Ditor manual<%11> (.pdf) to chapter <%2>IN-GAME FUNCTIONS<%3> (page 94).

Key.Original: Cloning emitters
Key.English: Cloning emitters

Key.Original:
<%2>Cloning emitters<%3>

The emitters inserted via this tool do not support the normal Eden copy/paste which is why this cloning feature exists.
This is also the case with the Eden entities that have emitters set via their attributes ('attribute emitters').

<%10><%2>IMPORTANT NOTE:<%3><%3>
Cloning supports only one emitter, or one entity with attribute emitters at one time. Meaning you can NOT clone more than one emitter or said entity at once.
Emitter sets behave as one emitter so cloning an emitter belonging into a emitter set will clone the whole set.

<%11>NOTE that possible trigger syncs do not clone, this clones only the emitter or the entity with attribute emitters.<%3>
Key.English:
<%2>Cloning emitters<%3>

The emitters inserted via this tool do not support the normal Eden copy/paste which is why this cloning feature exists.
This is also the case with the Eden entities that have emitters set via their attributes ('attribute emitters').

<%10><%2>IMPORTANT NOTE:<%3><%3>
Cloning supports only one emitter, or one entity with attribute emitters at one time. Meaning you can NOT clone more than one emitter or said entity at once.
Emitter sets behave as one emitter so cloning an emitter belonging into a emitter set will clone the whole set.

<%11>NOTE that possible trigger syncs do not clone, this clones only the emitter or the entity with attribute emitters.<%3>

Key.Original:
Cloning can be done by two ways:
by pressing the <%2>Clone<%3> button or via a keyboard shortcut <%10>SHIFT + CTRL + C<%3>.

Select the emitter you wish to clone and use either way to clone it. The clone will appear at a random position around the original emitter.

In case of cloning an entity with attribute emitters you can select either the entity itself or the emitter.
Key.English:
Cloning can be done by two ways:
by pressing the <%2>Clone<%3> button or via a keyboard shortcut <%10>SHIFT + CTRL + C<%3>.

Select the emitter you wish to clone and use either way to clone it. The clone will appear at a random position around the original emitter.

In case of cloning an entity with attribute emitters you can select either the entity itself or the emitter.

Key.Original: 'Attribute Emitters'
Key.English: 'Attribute Emitters'

Key.Original:
<%2>'Attribute Emitters'<%3>

This may sound odd but using this to describe emitters set to Eden entities via their attributes.

This is the “true” Eden way of adding emitters, via an entity's attributes. Not all entity types are supported (those which would not make sense to have these attributes). Map objects are also not supported. It is not possible to edit the parameters of these emitters from within the attributes, but it is possible to edit them via the Emitter 3Ditor after setting them up.

To set up these attribute emitters open some entity's attributes and collapse the Emitter 3Ditor section, then check the box 'Use as emitter'.
Key.English:
<%2>'Attribute Emitters'<%3>

This may sound odd but using this to describe emitters set to Eden entities via their attributes.

This is the “true” Eden way of adding emitters, via an entity's attributes. Not all entity types are supported (those which would not make sense to have these attributes). Map objects are also not supported. It is not possible to edit the parameters of these emitters from within the attributes, but it is possible to edit them via the Emitter 3Ditor after setting them up.

To set up these attribute emitters open some entity's attributes and collapse the Emitter 3Ditor section, then check the box 'Use as emitter'.

Key.Original:
You can set up to 4 emitters per entity, emitters can be both particle or light emitters.
You can set a particle or light class to each emitter, or if you have already used the main tool and saved parameter presets those can be used here as well.

If the object in question has named selections in it's 3D model you can also select to attach the given emitter to a selection. Each emitter can be at it's own selection.

You can also name each emitter individually.

If you wish to alter the parameters for these emitters open the Emitter 3Ditor tool.
Key.English:
You can set up to 4 emitters per entity, emitters can be both particle or light emitters.

If the object in question has named selections in it's 3D model you can also select to attach the given emitter to a selection. Each emitter can be at it's own selection.

You can also name each emitter individually.

If you wish to alter the parameters for these emitters open the Emitter 3Ditor tool.
